title-group.article-title: Effect of refinery waste effluent on tocopherol, carotenoid, phenolics and other antioxidants content in Allium cepa

contrib-group.aff: Department of Biochemistry, Aligarh Muslim University, India

author-notes.corresp: Masood Ahmad, Department of Biochemistry, Aligarh Muslim University, Aligarh, 202002 UP, India. Email: masood_amua@yahoo.co.in

abstract.p: Pollution in water used for irrigation is a major cause of stress generation in plant system. Under these stress conditions, reactive oxygen species derived from molecular oxygen can accumulate in plant, resulting in the oxidation of nucleic acids, lipids, chlorophyll and so on. This study was conducted in Allium cepa to analyze the alteration in the levels of nonenzymatic antioxidants as a consequence of Mathura refinery waste water (MRWW) exposure. The studied antioxidants were glutathione (GSH) and ascorbic acid (ASC). Their determination was carried out in A. cepa bulbs exposed to different concentrations of MRWW that is 0.25×, 0.5×, 0.75× and 1.0×. A significant increase in the levels of these nonenzymatic antioxidants in onion bulbs upon treatment with MRWW suggested that these can serve as suitable biomarkers of toxicity. The toxicity of waste water was also tested on the level of tocopherol (Toc) and carotenoid (CAR) in onion bulbs, and in both the cases a high level of these metabolites was noticed. Phenolic content of A. cepa after the waste water insult was found to be increased, again a manifestation of adaptation against heavy metal and oxidative stress. It is clear from our findings that GSH, ASC, Toc and CAR in A. cepa system could serve as potential biomarkers for the presence of toxicants like heavy metals and its hazards in MRWW. The test waste water demonstrated profound effects on these parameters which is suggestive of the warrior strategies adopted by the plant system against the pollution-induced stress.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Refinery waste water (RWW) is a very complex and variable mixture which is released into rivers and lakes (Heidarzadeh et al., 2010). The sludge that results from various treatment processes in oil refinery has a high content of petroleum-derived hydrocarbons, mainly alkanes and paraffins of 1–40 carbon atoms, along with cycloalkanes, aromatic compounds and heavy metals (Overcash and Pal, 1979), making them a potentially dangerous waste product.

There has been a growing need to monitor and check the pollution of RWW. Present study was designed to explore whether Allium cepa system could serve as a potential candidate for RWW biomonitoring. A. cepa is the common onion and has been widely used in all parts of the world as a flavouring vegetable. A. cepa root-length inhibition bioassay has been recommended for the routine monitoring of water pollution since it is quite sensitive and a valid indicator of toxicity (Fiskesjo, 1985; Gupta and Ahmad, 2011). A. cepa has been well documented to respond to externally imposed stress, like that of heavy metals, organic solvents, trichloroethylene (TCE), pesticides, and hence serves as plausible candidate for biomonitoring the pesticides/heavy metal/TCE pollution (Fatima and Ahmad, 2006; Tabrez and Ahmad, 2010).

Plants functioning in an aerobic environment are often subjected to continuous threat from molecular oxygen which is converted into toxic reactive oxygen species (ROS) like superoxide radical (O2 γ−), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), hydroxyl radical (OHγ−) and so on (Khan and Panda, 2002). These ROS have the capacity to degrade almost all cell components including membrane lipids, proteins and DNA. Toxic hydrogen peroxide is a product of peroxisomal and chloroplast oxidative reactions and can act both as an oxidant and as a reductant. It is the most stable form of the ROS and is capable of rapid diffusion across cell membrane (Del Rio et al., 1992).

Heavy metals are known to cause irreversible damage to a number of vital metabolic constituents and important biomolecules. They also cause irreversible injury to the plant cell and its membrane (Chandra and Kulshreshtha, 2004). Therefore, heavy metal analysis seemed to be necessary both in the test water sample and in the exposed A. cepa bulbs.

The toxic effects of ROS are counteracted by both the enzymatic and the nonenzymatic antioxidant systems such as superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT), glutathione peroxidase (GPX), ascorbate peroxidases (APXs), ascorbic acids (ASCs), glutathione (GSH), tocopherol (Toc; Ahmad et al., 2008; Gupta and Ahmad, 2011). Normally cellular compartment contains more than one enzymatic activity that detoxifies particular ROS: for example, the cytosol contains at least three enzymatic activities that scavenge H2O2—that is APX, GPX and peroxiredoxin (Nobuhiro and Mittler, 2006).

GSH is the major nonprotein thiol and a versatile antioxidant in most plants, prokaryotes and animals. GSH is involved in the enzymatic detoxification of activated oxygen species and participates in the ASC-GSH cycle, for peroxide removal in the chloroplasts of plants. Its function in stress reactions is well established (Gill and Tuteja, 2010).

Ascorbate (ASC) is a major metabolite in plants. It is an antioxidant and, in association with other components of the antioxidant system, protects plants against oxidative damage resulting from aerobic metabolism, photosynthesis and a range of pollutants (Drazkiewicz et al., 2003). ASC is also a cofactor for certain enzymes. ASC occurs in the cell wall where it provides a first line of defence against ozone (Smirnoff and Pallanca, 1996).

Toc is a lipid-soluble antioxidant found in all plant parts and is a potential scavenger of ROS and lipid radicals (Kruk et al., 2005). α-Toc is the major vitamin E found in leaf chloroplasts, where it is located in the chloroplast envelope, thylakoid membranes and plastoglobuli, and functions both as an antioxidant and as a nonantioxidant (Bosch, 2005). Toc prevents the chain propagation step in lipid auto-oxidation, and this makes it an effective free radical trap (Serbinova and Packer, 1994). In addition, Toc acts as a scavenger of oxygen radicals, especially O2 γ− (Fryer, 1992).

Carotenoids (CARs) are the pigments that are found in plants and micro-organisms. There are over 600 CARs occurring in nature. These lipid-soluble antioxidants play a multitude of functions in plant metabolism including oxidative stress. CARs harbour light energy and transfer it to chlorophyll. They also protect the photosynthetic apparatus by quenching a triplet sensitizer, singlet oxygen and other harmful free radicals which are naturally formed during photosynthesis (Ahmad et al., 2009). They are responsible for the orange colour of the carrot, for which this class of chemicals is named, and for the colours of many other fruits and vegetables, such as sweet potatoes and orange cantaloupe melon (Anderson, 1994).

All plants produce an amazing diversity of secondary metabolites. One of the most important groups of these metabolites is the phenolic compound. An increased phenylopropanoid metabolism as well as the amount of phenolic compounds has been reported under different environmental factors and stress conditions (Diaz et al., 2001; Sakihama and Yamasaki, 2002).

The functions of the aforementioned biomolecules under stress conditions are well established (Ahmad et al., 2009; Gill and Tuteja, 2010). Hence, their levels could serve as a good estimate of oxidative stress generated in the plant system exposed to MRWW. Moreover, application of sewage sludge on agricultural, arable fields for enhancing productivity has been a common practice in India, for many years. Use of surface water, obviously contaminated with various toxicants, for agricultural purpose is also well known. Continuous use of waste water for irrigation leads to the enrichment of micronutrients including heavy metals in the soil (Singh and Agrawal, 2010). Nutritional status of vegetables like onion especially obtained by irrigation with water carrying the refinery waste seemed to be essential to study the harmful effect of RWW. Furthermore, present investigation was also aimed at the estimation of various antioxidants and pro-oxidants in the A. cepa system exposed to RWW.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Ascorbate oxidase, nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide, horseradish peroxidase (HRPO) and perchloric acid were obtained from Sigma Chem. Co. (St Louis, Missouri, USA). Calf thymus DNA, phenol red, dextrose, nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT), triton-X-100, sulphosalicylic acid, dinitrophenyl hydrazine, 5,5′-dithio-bis-2-nitrobenzoic acid (DTNB) and thiourea were obtained from SRL, Chemicals, Mumbai, India. ASC and thiobarbituric acid were obtained from Himedia Laboratories Pvt. Ltd (Mumbai). Tricarboxylic acid was collected from Qualigens Fine Chemical (Mumbai). All other chemicals and reagents were of analytical grade. The small bulbs of A. cepa (red variety) were purchased from the local market. The waste water was collected from the surrounding area of Mathura refinery, Mathura, UP (India) in sterile glass bottles as per the method described by APHA (2005). Prior to use, the particulate matter was removed by means of filtration using Whatman No. 1 filter paper.

Present study was based on the exposure of A. cepa (onion) to different concentrations of Mathura refinery waste water (MRWW) that is 0.25×, 0.5×, 0.75× and 1.0× along with untreated control to estimate the levels of certain nonenzymatic antioxidant biomolecules.

sec.title: Moderate exposure of A. cepa to MRWW
sec.p: The basic protocol of Fiskesjo (1985) was followed with slight modification. Test tubes (60 ml capacity) filled with serially diluted MRWW (0.25×, 0.50×, 0.75× and 1.0×) were taken and on each test tube one onion bulb was placed. Aquaguard-purified water was used as the negative control in all the experiments. The treatment was continued for 2 days in a dark chamber at room temperature. After 2 days, all the onion bulbs were taken out and used for enzymatic studies.

sec.title: Homogenate preparation (for GSH, ASC and free radicals estimations)
sec.p: All the treated and control onion bulbs were cut into small pieces and homogenized in chilled sodium phosphate buffer (50 mM, pH 7.4) containing 1 mM EDTA. The homogenate was squeezed through muslin cloth and the extract obtained was centrifuged at 8000 r/min for 25 min at 4°C. Clear supernatant was stored at −5 to −10°C in vials. The vials were properly thawed just prior to nonenzymatic analysis.

sec.title: Heavy metal analysis in A. cepa bulbs exposed to MRWW
sec.p: Dried plant sample (1 g) was digested with 10 ml of ternary acid (HNO3, H2SO4 and HClO4 mixture in 5:1:1 ratio) at 80°C until a transparent solution was obtained (Singh and Agrawal, 2010). Water samples (50 ml) were digested in 10 ml of concentrated HNO3 at 80°C until the solution became transparent (APHA, 2005). The concentrations of heavy metals in the filtrates were determined by atomic absorption spectrophotometer (GBC 932, Plus Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometer Braeside, Victoria, Australia).

sec.title: Nonenzymatic analysis
sec.p: GSH estimation. GSH levels were estimated by the method of Jollow et al. (1974), in 100 μl of A. cepa homogenates using the classical thiol reagent DTNB (0.1 mol L−1 phosphate buffer, pH 7.4) at 25°C. The yellow colour developed by the reaction of GSH with DTNB was read at 412 nm.

ASC estimation. ASC content was determined using the bipyridyl method as described by Knorzer et al. (1996). An ASC standard calibration curve was previously run, and an extinction coefficient of 16.5 mol (L cm)−1 was obtained. For the determination of ASC contents, A. cepa homogenates (125 μl) were neutralized with 25 μl of 1.5 mol L−1 triethanolamine, and after mixing, 150 μl of 150 mmol L−1 sodium phosphate (pH 7.4) and 150 μl of water were added. For the determination of total ASC (ASC + docosahexaenoic acid), the samples were neutralized, phosphate buffer and water were added and then 75 μl of 10 mmol L−1 dithiothreitol was added and incubated for 15 min at room temperature. The absorbance of the reaction mixture was recorded at 525 nm.

Toc estimation. Toc content was assayed as described by Backer et al. (1980). Five grams of fresh tissue was homogenized with 100 ml of a mixture of petroleum ether and ethanol (2:1.6, v/v), and the extract was centrifuged at 10,000 r/min for 20 min and the supernatant was used for estimation of Toc. To 1 ml of the extract, 200 μl of 2% 2,2-dipyridyl in ethanol was added and mixed thoroughly and kept in dark for 5 min. The resulting red colour was diluted with 4 ml of distilled water and mixed well. The colour in the aqueous layer was measured at 520 nm. The Toc content was calculated using a standard graph made with known amount of Toc.

CAR estimation. The estimation of CAR in onion bulbs was done by the method of Dere et al. (1998). Ten grams of fresh tissue was homogenized with 250 ml of ether. Homogenate was filtered through two layered cheese cloth and the supernatant was centrifuged at 2500 r/min for 10 min. The supernatant was separated and the absorbance was recorded at 470 nm.

Total phenolic estimation. Total phenol was estimated by the method of Malick and Singh (1980). Five grams of fresh plant tissue was ground in a pestle and mortar with 100 ml of 80% ethanol. The homogenate was centrifuged at 10,000 r/min for 20 min. The supernatant was evaporated to dryness. The residue obtained was dissolved with 100 ml of distilled water and used as extract. To 2 ml of the extract, 500 μl of Folin-Ciocalteau reagent was added. After 3 min, 2 ml of 20% Na2CO3 solution was added and mixed thoroughly. The mixture was kept in boiling water for exactly 1 min and after cooling the absorbance was read at 650 nm (phenols react with phosphomolybdic acid in Folin-Ciocalteau reagent in alkaline medium and produce blue coloured complex called molybdenum blue). Total phenol was determined using a standard curve prepared using different concentrations of gallic acid (0.1%).

Hydrogen peroxide estimation. The amount of H2O2 was estimated by the HRPO-mediated oxidation of phenol red by H2O2 (Pick and Keisari, 1980). Reaction mixture containing 200 μl homogenates, 2.8 ml of phenol red solution (140 mM NaCl, 10 mM potassium phosphate buffer pH 7.0, 5.5 mM dextrose, 0.28 mM phenol red and 8.5 U/ml HRPO), was incubated at 37°C for 10 min in fully covered tubes. At the completion of incubation, the reaction mixture was centrifuged for 5 min at 2500 r/min at 4°C. The supernatant obtained after centrifugation was decanted into a fresh tube and 1 mol L−1 NaOH was added to each tube. The samples were read at 610 nm.

Hydroxyl radicals estimation. The estimation of OH radical in onion bulbs was done by taking 100 μl of homogenate, 150 μl of Tris-HCl buffer (0.01 M, pH 7.5) and 300 μl of DNA (3 mM) which was then incubated for 1 h at 37°C. The reaction was stopped by adding 1.2 ml of 28% trichloroacetic acid. After that 1.2 ml of 1% thiobarbituric acid was added and the test tubes were kept in boiling water bath for 15 min. Absorbance of the contents was measured at 532 nm after cooling the test tubes (Richmond et al., 1981).

Superoxide radical estimation. The estimation of O2 γ− was done by NBT-based calorimetric method (Nakayama et al., 1983). Three millilitre of the reaction mixture contained 300 μl of sodium phosphate buffer (100 mM, pH 8), 100 μl of NBT (1 mM), 300 μl of Triton-X-100 (0.6%), 2.2 ml of distilled water, 100 μl of homogenate and the absorbance was read at 560 nm.

sec.title: Statistical evaluation
sec.p: Five onions were used per treatment. Data were expressed as mean ± SD of three replicates from three independent experiments and analyzed using one-way analysis of variance. Differences among controls and treatments were determined using Student’s t test. p Values of less than 0.05 were considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Table 1 presents the heavy metal contents in MRWW, whereas Table 2 indicates the concentration of certain heavy metal in A. cepa bulbs exposed to MRWW for 2 days. The data presented in this table show that the onion bulbs exert some sort of barrier against the penetration of heavy metals. However, some ions of the heavy metal gained entry into the onion bulbs. Figure 1 depicts the level of GSH estimated in A. cepa bulbs after treatment with MRWW. A concentration-dependent increase in GSH levels was noticed with increasing magnitude at higher concentrations. Maximum GSH level was estimated at 1× MRWW, where it showed an enhancement of 76% from the control value. Figure 2 presents the induction of ASC in A. cepa as a result of MRWW exposure. A rise of around 64% in ASC level was observed at 1× concentration of MRWW. Figure 3 presents the changes recorded in consequent Toc level upon MRWW treatment in A. cepa bulbs. The Toc levels were also found to be increased upon MRWW exposure. However, a nominal enhancement occurred at 0.25× concentration of MRWW, whereas more than 50% induction in Toc levels was registered at 0.75× concentration. MRWW-exposure-induced enhancement in nonenzymatic antioxidants was highest for GSH, and Toc followed closely to 72% increase at 1× concentration of MRWW. Figure 4 illustrates CAR level (μg/gram fresh weight) in A. cepa bulbs exposed to different concentrations of MRWW. A rise of around 76% in CAR level was observed at 1× concentration of MRWW. A similar trend of enhancement was also found in the level of phenolics (Figure 5), which displayed an induction of 68% at 1× concentration of MRWW.

caption.p: Glutathione levels in Allium cepa bulbs exposed to increasing concentrations (0.25×, 0.5×, 0.75× and 1×) of Mathura refinery waste water. All the data were significantly different at p < 0.05. *Indicates significance at p < 0.05 compared to control.

Ascorbate levels in Allium cepa bulbs exposed to increasing concentrations (0.25×, 0.5×, 0.75× and 1×) of Mathura refinery waste water. All the data were significantly different at p < 0.05. *Indicates significance at p < 0.05 compared to control.

Tocopherol levels in Allium cepa bulbs exposed to increasing concentrations (0.25×, 0.5×, 0.75× and 1×) of Mathura refinery waste water. All the data were significantly different at p < 0.05. *Indicates significance at p < 0.05 compared to control.

Carotenoid levels in Allium cepa bulbs exposed to increasing concentrations (0.25×, 0.5×, 0.75× and 1×) of Mathura refinery waste water. All the data were significantly different at p < 0.05. *Indicates significance at p < 0.05 compared to control.

Levels of total phenolics in Allium cepa bulbs exposed to increasing concentrations (0.25×, 0.5×, 0.75× and 1×) of Mathura refinery waste water. All the data were significantly different at p < 0.05. *Indicates significance at p < 0.05 compared to control.
Concentrations of certain heavy metals in MRWW analyzed by atomic absorption spectrophotometer.
Concentrations of selected heavy metals in Allium cepa bulbs exposed to Mathura refinery waste water.

sec.p: To validate the induction of oxidative stress upon MRWW exposure, the levels of H2O2, OHγ and O2 γ were also measured in treated and control bulbs. As expected, the level of all ROS studied by us decreased with increased concentration of MRWW (Figures 6, 7, and 8). The decrease was almost in the same range (60%) for all ROS.

caption.p: Profile of hydrogen peroxide generation in Allium cepa bulbs exposed to increasing concentrations (0.25×, 0.5×, 0.75× and 1×) of Mathura refinery waste water. All the data were significantly different at p < 0.05. *Indicates significance at p < 0.05 compared to control.

Profile of hydroxyl radical levels in Allium cepa bulbs exposed to increasing concentrations (0.25×, 0.5×, 0.75× and 1×) of Mathura refinery waste water. All the data were significantly different at p < 0.05. *Indicates significance at p < 0.05 compared to control.

Profile of superoxide radical levels in Allium cepa bulbs exposed to increasing concentrations (0.25×, 0.5×, 0.75× and 1×) of Mathura refinery waste water. All the data were significantly different at p < 0.05. *Indicates significance at p < 0.05 compared to control.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: It is well known that RWW exposure induces an alteration in enzymatic and nonenzymatic antioxidant defence system of the exposed organism (Ilangovan and Vivekanandan, 1992; Khan et al., 2001). However, very few reports have documented the effect in plant system. This study explores the alterations in nonenzymatic antioxidants of model plant system, A. cepa, exposed to varying concentrations of MRWW. GSH, ASC, Toc and CAR levels were quantified in MRWW-exposed onions and compared with untreated control. The enhancement in the level of these antioxidants would be an indication of the toxicity of MRWW on A. cepa system (Gill and Tuteja, 2010).

A. cepa is a simple vegetable and offers a good experimental model for in vivo evaluation of toxicity of pure chemicals and complex mixture (Lerda et al., 2010). It has been reported that roots of A. cepa are very useful in toxicity testing because the root tips are often the first to be exposed to chemicals in the water and soil (Abu and Mba, 2010); and therefore, A. cepa toxicity test is used all over the world (Grant, 1999).

The test antioxidants are found at high concentrations in chloroplasts as well as in other cellular compartments and present a major defence function against oxidative stress (Noctor and Foyer, 1998). In the present study, the effect of the MRWW on nutrient contents and antioxidant status in A. cepa (onion) was investigated. The level of ASC, GSH, Toc, CAR and phenolics was found to be increased after MRWW treatment as compared to control (Figures 1–5). These are the major nonenzymatic biomolecules of antioxidant system which are required for the detoxification of ROS (Ahmad et al., 2009; McKersie et al., 1990). ASC and GSH are considered as the most important antioxidants involved in protection against ROS/free radicals through the ASC/GSH cycle (Drazkiewicz et al., 2003; Kuzniak and Maria, 2001; Tabrez and Ahmad, 2010). A rise in GSH level (76%) and ASC level (64%) with respect to control may account for the significant reduction in free radical levels.

GSH functions as an antioxidant in many ways. It can react chemically with singlet oxygen as well as superoxide and hydroxyl radicals, and thus functions directly as a free radical scavenger (Valko et al., 2007). The ASC-GSH cycle also plays an important role in maintaining the ASC level (Hancock and Viola, 2005; Noctor and Foyer, 1998). In addition to the importance of ASC-GSH cycle, it plays a role in preventing the activities of enzymes that contain prosthetic group. In this way, ASC and GSH are recycled when H2O2 is scavenged in living cells.

A significant increase in GSH content was recorded by Mishra et al. (2006) in Bacopa monnieri L. exposed to heavy metal, Cd2+. The increased level of GSH during Cd2+ stress may possibly be due to induced transcription of the genes for GSH biosynthesis such as γ-glutamylcysteine synthetase and glutathione synthetase (Xiang and Oliver, 1998). Zengin and Munzuroglu (2005) reported a remarkable induction in ASC level in Phaseolus vulgaris L. under the treatment of heavy metal mixture.

Tocs significantly contribute to the plant tolerance against oxidative stress (Bosch, 2005). They interact with the polyunsaturated acyl group of lipids, stabilize membrane, scavenge and quench various ROS and lipid-soluble by-products of oxidative stress (Shao et al., 2006). The induction in Toc level in onion bulbs following MRWW exposure is also indicative of oxidative stress generated by toxicants present in the test waste water (Figure 3). This draws support from previous workers who demonstrated that oxidative stress actually triggered synthesis of certain low-molecular-weight antioxidants like Toc by activating their genes in some plants (Shao and Chu, 2005; Wu et al., 2007). This antioxidant somehow deactivates photosynthesis-derived ROS (mainly O2 γ− and OHγ) and prevents the propagation of lipid peroxidation by scavenging lipid peroxyl radicals in thylakoid membranes.

The induction in CAR levels in MRWW-treated onion bulbs can serve as a good biomarker of some toxicants, like hydrocarbons and/or heavy metals, in the test waste water (Foyer and Harbioson, 1994; Siefermann-Hams, 1987). This waste water-imposed insult was obviously sufficient to induce the CAR levels which were found to be positively correlated with the concentrations of MRWW (Figure 4). Singh and Sinha (2005) also reported an increased CAR content in Brassica juncea L. grown on soil amended with tannery waste.

Phenolics possess hydroxyl and carboxyl groups with the ability to bind metal ions in particular (Jung et al., 2003). Antioxidant action of phenolic compounds is due to their high tendency to chelate metal ions. Moreover, Ilangovan and Vivekanandan (1992) reported a high level of total phenolic compounds in the leaves of Vigna mungo L., Hepper plant grown in oil-polluted soil containing high level of hydrocarbons. Present study clearly suggests that the induction in the levels of phenolic compounds in A. cepa bulbs might be due to the interference of both the heavy metals and the hydrocarbons present in MRWW (Figure 5, Table 1; communicated data). The enhanced levels of phenolic compounds were recorded in several plants against the exposure with heavy metals (Agrawal and Deepak, 2003; Arora et al., 1998; Giertych et al., 1999; Rice-Evans et al., 1997). In fact, phenolics are supposed to facilitate the chelation of metal ions and thus to prevent ROS production through Fenton’s reaction (Rice-Evans et al., 1997).

A uniform rise in the levels of reduced GSH, ASC, Toc and CAR as a result of MRWW exposure to A. cepa bulbs can also serve as a potential biomarker for RWW toxicity. In fact, A. cepa root inhibition test is a cost-effective toxicity bioassay routinely used in water-monitoring studies (Fiskesjo, 1985). Therefore, its efficacy would be greatly increased if antioxidant studies are also included in the same onion bulbs exposed to the sample for the standard A. cepa bioassay.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Waste water stress signalling in plants is an important area of studies to activate their nonenzymatic defence system. Therefore, the basic understanding of the mechanisms underlying the functioning of stress genes is important for the survival of plant under stress. Based on our present study, we conclude that GSH and ASC in A. cepa system could serve as a potential biomarker for the presence of toxicants like heavy metals and their hazards. A. cepa system can also be successfully used for monitoring the changes in the levels of nonenzymatic biomolecules as a result of exposure with MRWW. Phenolic compounds could be a major determinant of antioxidant potential of food plants. The enhanced level of Toc and CAR implies that the stress was sufficient to affect the plant system in a variety of ways.

fn.p: The authors declared that there is no conflict of interest.

fn.p: Amit Kumar Gupta was a junior research fellow of UP CST, Lucknow, India. The authors gratefully acknowledge the financial assistance to the department by the UGC, New Delhi, under its DRS-II program.
